Award.AwardTitle: PREM-The University of Texas Pan American/University of Minnesota -Science and Engineering of Polymeric and Nanoparticle-based Materials for Electronic and Structural Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Partnership for Research and Education in Materials (PREM) creates a partnership between the University of Texas Pan American (UTPA) and the University of Minnesota (UMN) Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) focused on the development of polymeric and nanoparticle based materials and devices. While this collaboration builds upon the growing research activity at UTPA, this PREM embodies the first science and engineering collaboration of this magnitude at UTPA. Research conducted in this partnership are in five thrusts: (1) the exploration of nanoparticle-based materials, such as laser-induced aggregation of nanocrystallites as well as nanoparticles-in-photonic crystal material systems, for applications to photovoltaic solar cells, (2) the development of soluble conjugated polymers for spin-processable, low cost, plastic light emitters as well as conjugated-polymer-in-photonic crystal system low-threshold lasers, (3) the functionalization of nanoporous materials for the application of mechanical-to-interfacial energy conversion, (4) the development of self-healing polymeric materials with block copolymers for smart flexible materials applications, and (5) the study of nanoreinforced polymeric composite-thin film and metal-thin film interfaces to improve the mechanical properties of these systems.

Materials science educational outreach is performed utilizing existing UTPA programs such as Upward Bound, GearUp and Tex-Prep programs. In addition to these outreach activities, this PREM also presents materials science sessions to K-12 students and participates in the Research Experience for Teachers (RET) program for science teachers hosted at the partner UMN MRSEC. Besides the education and outreach to the community in general, this PREM increases the participation of women STEM faculty members and promotes their retention in materials research as more than 57% of the UTPA participating faculty are women.

Institution.Name: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley

ProgramReference.Text: RET SITE-Res Exp for Tchr Site
RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UTPA-UMN partnership was the platform to the development of the first research intensive materials science/engineering center of excellence at UTPA, non PhD Hispanic institution. Prior to PREM there was no venue to promote research in materials science at UTPA. The PREM forged an interdisciplinary team (five departments within UTPA). Some of the PREM Outcomes are listed below:

  • 139 students conducted research for the PREM, 22 MS (63% URM), 111 UG (93% URM), and six PhD (5 at UMN and one at UNT).
  • 100% retention and graduation
  • 76 peer reviewed journal publications (63% co-authored with students and 82% co-authored by students and postdocs)
  • 127 proceedings/presentations at conferences (86% co-auuthored by UG students)
  • The technical projects resulted in 6 patent applications, one licensed to date.
  • 92 UG students have graduated, 40 decided to enroll in graduate programs (MS, PhD and/or MD) at Rice U, Georgia Tech, Vanderbilt U, Texas A&M, UMN, and Tufts University to mention some). 
  • Over 2,500 k-12 students benefited from the multiple outreach activities led by UTPA PREM faculty (Girl in Engineering, NEURONS, Parent's career awareness, HESTEC, ABC of Science, etc).
  • Four UTPA professors received the UT Regent's Outstanding Teaching Award.

 

Acronyms: URM (Underrepresented minority); REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates); UTPA (University of Texas Pan American); UMN (University of Minnesota); UNT (university of North Texas).


Last Modified: 12/14/2016
Modified by: Karen Lozano
